title: History and use of stencil fonts
content:
I am trying to research the history and use of stencil fonts, but I am finding that the only references I come across lead me to a particular font. That is okay, but what I want to know is why and typically where they are used and some examples of their use.

Is ESPN an example of a stencil font?

 [‹ At last: Fontshop.com has removed the redirect](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/www.typophile.com/node/37986 "Go to previous forum topic") [Lacking ascenders? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/www.typophile.com/node/37964 "Go to next forum topic")

Stencils were/are also popular with draftsmen, architects and designers. Some information about the Bodoni stencil used by designer Le Corbusier [Here](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/typographica.org/000490.php) and [Here](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/www.lamidesign.com/pages/notes/fonts/modsten1.html).

In [Typography Papers 5](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/typography/home.html?publications/typo_papers/index.html) You’ll find a rather thorough presentation of _stencil letters and associated artefacts of the past four centuries_ by [Eric Kindel](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/typography/home.html?staff/academic/eric_k.html). He’s also written on the subject in [Baseline 38](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/www.baselinemagazine.com/mainframe/Baseline/other_issues/issue_38/issue%2038_8page.html). I think he’s the go-to guy when it comes to stencil lettering, but I assume James Moseley who’s occasionally contributing to Typophile has something interesting to add as well.

Eric Kindel at the University of Reading has done extensive research on what are the predecessors to stencil fonts, if you are interested in going that far back. I’m aware of 2 papers, the first in Typography Papers 5 and the second in Typography Papers 7; as well as at least one in Eye and another in Baseline. His line of work, I am sure, has good bibliography information. You can reach him through the Typography Department’s site. [http://www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/home.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20080925080814/http:/www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/home.html "http://www.rdg.ac.uk/AcaDepts/lt/home.html")
I know Eric from when I was at Reading and have followed his research through his writings.

Lucky you to know someone that covers a subject that I am trying to find more information about.

”...teams such as the Pittsburgh Steelers”

Besides the military uses mentioned, industrial uses of stencils were quite prominent and most likely predated military usage. I grew up in Pittsburgh in the 40s and 50s. I had summer jobs in mills and factories. Stencils were used to mark material for easy retrieval in a warehouse. They were an efficient way to mark numerous crates over and over on all sides so that they can be read from any vantage point. Since

Pittsburgh was above all an industrial town, It makes sense that the Steelers would follow the lead of the steel industry and give their logo an industrial look.

ChrisL

BTW, This is the Steelers 75th anniversary year so that should give you a point in time to look at. In the 1930s Pittsburgh was known as the smokey city and steel capital of the world. Heavy wooden crates of steel products were common and all stenciled.  
The United States Steel Corporation also had a stencil logo and the symbol of the Steelers is taken directly from the old Steel Industry symbol.

ChrisL

And the Minnesota Vikings old logo font? I was thinking it was used because the old scoreboards I thought used stencil numbers.

It’s a little bit funny actually. The wiki doesn’t mention the fact that most stencil faces have taken on that look, from laziness. The patterns were originally made to improve hand painting of letters where such expertise was lacking, (Pittsburgh perhaps and the Military most certainly being good examples). After the islands were painted, the “so simple a private can do it” bridges were s’posed to be painted as well to make it look like there was an expert involved. Oh well ;)
